subject: RE: [junit] New Classes when refactoring
msgSnippet: Mike That is how I read Fowler s comments.  That seems to break the pattern of a test class for each class.  When if every do you go back and create a test
messageBody:
Mike

That is how I read Fowler's comments. That seems to break the pattern of a
test class
for each class. When if every do you go back and create a test class that
just tests the
new class?

Randy

-----Original Message-----
From: Mike Clark [mailto:mike@...]
Sent: Thursday, June 14, 2001 9:29 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] New Classes when refactoring


--- "Cox, Randy" <randy.cox@...> wrote:
> I picked Refactoring - Martin Fowler up at Java One. The question I
> have
> is: When you add new class during refactoring, perhaps adding a
> "value
> object" or "replacing conditional logic with polymorphism" do you
> test it
> through your original JUnit Tests or do you build a new Test class
> for the
> new class.
>

One of the preconditions for refactoring is the existence of a test
case which is then used to verify that the refactoring didn't break
anything. So, I claim that you should always use your original test,
and then add more if necessary.

Mike
